testimony:
Good afternoon.  We want to start the proceedings.  For the record, it's Wednesday the 10th of May 2000, it is the continuation of the sitting of the Amnesty Committee at Middelburg.  The Panel is constituted as would be apparent from the record.  We just wish to indicate that the proceedings are starting late today, due to a number of logistical and other difficulties that have largely been occasioned by the fact that all of the applicants in all of the applications that are on our roll for today, are in custody in different centres and they had to be transported from these centres to Middelburg, where we are sitting, which is the most central point for the matters that are on the roll for this particular session in Middelburg.
	The situation has been exacerbated by the fact that at some of the centres, Correctional Services has not had its normal staff component, resulting in pressure on the diminished resources that were available, and that affected us and delayed the proceedings here because some of the applicants had to be transported over considerable distances to the venue.  We apologise for the delay in being able to start.  We do intend to, if it's at all possible, finalise the matters that are on the roll for today and if needs be, for that purpose we will consider continuing the session till beyond the normal sitting hours, in order to be able to do so.
	The matters that are to be heard now are the applications of D L Phasha, amnesty reference AM1319/96, L L Phasha, reference AM1318/96 and M M Phasha, reference AM1221/96.  
	I'm going to allow the legal representatives to put themselves on record.  I'll start with Mr Richard.
Thank you, Chair.  Tony Richard, Johannesburg.  I am appearing for the Phashas, the applicants.

Thank you, Mr Richard.
Thank you, Honourable Chairperson.  I'm Frank Mokoena from Nelspruit, I'm representing the victims.
Thank you, Mr Mokoena.  And then the Leader of Evidence.
I'm Lula Mtanga, Chairperson.  Thank you.
Thank you, Ms Mtanga.  Yes, Mr Richard?
Thank you, Chairperson.  I start by calling Michael Morudi Phasha, who is happy to be sworn.
Thank you, Mr Richard.  Mr Phasha, are your full names Michael Morudi Phasha?
Please stand to take the oath.
Thank you, you may be seated.  Mr Richard?

Thank you, Chairperson.
	Mr Phasha, where were you born?
I was born at Driekop, in the Northern Province.
And what is the nearest major centre to Driekop?
The smallest town is Burgersfort and the bigger on is Pietersburg.
Now is that where you were educated, reared and grew up, until your arrest in 1993?
Now what education did you receive?
I reached standard 10, but I did not finish standard 10.
Now am I correct in making the statement that the area is a rural area?
Am I also correct in saying that in this area the traditional structures of chiefs, their councillors, senior chiefs, junior chiefs, still exists and has existed throughout your life?
May you please repeat the question.

My question is, is it not correct that throughout your life, in the area where you have lived and grown up and led your life, the traditional structures of chiefs in villages, sub-chiefs and so on, still exist?

Now before we go into the essence of the matter, I've decided to use certain particular words and I'm going to ask the witness a number of questions.
	What is a moloi?  M-o-l-o-i.
It's somebody who kills people, using supernatural powers.
And what else do moloi's do?

Amongst other things that he does is to abduct people.  Those are the people that we know that they have died, but he knows that they did not die.  That is his secret and he will use those people the way he wants to use them.
And for what purposes would he use those people?

According to my little knowledge, amongst the purposes that he used them for include his personal things, or he together with his people who are doing the same thing that he's doing, that is other witches.
I go to the next term, and forgive my pronunciation.  The Sotho is ngaka, what is a ngaka?

He's the person who helps other people, people who believe in black traditions, by helping them and protecting them against the witches.  So his main duty is to protect them and also to expose some of the deeds of the witches.
Do ngakas also treat you when you're ill?
So a ngaka is more than just a traditional healer, he's also a person who points out molois.
Now how would a ngaka go about pointing out a moloi?

He uses different methods, it will depend on that particular traditional doctor, that is his training.  There are those who will be able to point the witch by using a mirror, and others, many others may use divine bones and they will read from the divine bones what is happening.

Now I give a hypothetical proposition, if I were a resident of a village such as the one that you come from, and had reason to suspect the work of a moloi, what would be the procedure for me to do?  How would I go about dealing with the problem?  Could I go to the chief, could I go to the ngaka, how would I process my complaint or question?

If that family is under the authority of a particular chief, they will go to that chief and he will give them advice as to what they should do, but other families they will go directly to the traditional doctor.  That would depend on the knowledge that they have about traditional doctors.
Now if the traditional doctors, or as we're calling them, ngaka, believe that witchcraft, a moloi, is involved, what role would the chief perform?
May you please repeat the question, Mr Tony Richards.

Thank you.  If the traditional doctor, ngaka, comes to the conclusion that there's the work of a moloi on hand, what would happen?  Who would be spoken to next, what procedures would be established, or followed?
The first thing that I know that the traditional doctor will do, will be to attend to the problem that you tell him about.  So it will also depend on you what type of help need from him.
What function would the chief fulfil?

What the chief does is to give directives and advices which will enable you to get help.  He may send you to a traditional doctor, the one that he believes that would be able to help, but his main task is not to heal like a traditional doctor, it's just to advise people and give them directives, as the leader in that particular village.
Thank you.  Now would you please tell the Committee and the Chairperson what are your beliefs regarding the powers of ngakas and molois.

My beliefs about the traditional doctor is that he is able to help a person who has problems, it can be family problems or sicknesses.  By talking about family problems I refer to, for example, from our beliefs as black people, we know about witches, so the traditional doctor will help him and give him protection.  My belief concerning the witches is that this is the person who is able to do things that other people may not be able to see them.  He will be the only person who sees those things, and such deeds can only be seen by a traditional doctor.
And you believe what the traditional doctors tell you and you believe what they say?
Because I grew up under that belief, yes, I do believe what the traditional doctor says because he's able to see what I cannot see.
Thank you.  Now sometime early in February, a person called Moses went missing, would you please tell the Committee what the relationship between Moses and you was.
Moses was my brother, but we had different mothers and our fathers were also brothers.  That is why I refer to him as my brother.
In other words, if I use the European classification and terminology, he would have been termed a cousin?  Your father's brother's child.
Now Moses grew up in the same area as you, did he not?
That is correct, we grew up together in the same village.
And did he have any political sympathies, did he support any political party?
He was the ANC supporter like myself.
Now what did Moses do to actively support the ANC?

His main involvement I would say, is that when the ANC Youth League was launched at our village, he was one of us.  We were together in fighting for the launching of the Youth League, but we did not have the membership cards, because that was the first time that we have a youth organisation in our area.
Now for how long before February '93, did the Youth League organisation of the ANC, exist in your village, Driekop?
When the ANC Youth League was launched, the ANC already existed, but for a period of not more than five years in our village.
So am I correct in drawing the inference that the late Moses was an ANC sympathiser and supporter for some number of years?  And well-known to be that.
Thank you.  Now if I understand this correctly and I have my chronology right, is it not correct that on the 15th of February, Moses' body was found and he was dead?
What I remember is that his corpse was found, but I do not recall the day in which his body was found.
His body was found at the mountain next to our village.
And in what condition was his body?
The body was already decomposing and it looked as if some of his body parts were missing.
Do you have any knowledge of what body parts were missing?

I remember his tongue, his teeth and the skin around his head.  The skull was actually exposed, and on his body he had a knife cut on his chest, but I was not able to see what was removed from his inside, but he had that wound.  It looked like a knife wound on his chest.
Now when you saw the body, would you agree that it bore the trademarks of what is called in the popular press, a muti killing?
Yes, that is what I believe.
Now how long before had the late Moses gone missing, was it a day, a week, two weeks, do you remember?
He went missing on the 16th of January 1983 - 1993, rather.
Was he well at the time he went missing?
Did he suffer from any ailments, any mental imbalance, pains in his side?
Yes, he was a sickly person, but his sickness at that period when it was suspected that it involved the - he was actually bewitched.
How do you know that he thought he was bewitched?

In his family - when he started becoming sick he was living with me, I was taking care of him, and he used to tell me that the people who made him to be ill, he gave me their names actually.  That is how I came to know that he was bewitched.
And who did he name as the molois or witch-doctors that were bewitching him?

The first one was Mamoghe Phasha.  The second one is Reisiki Phasha, and Reisibi Mashabela.  The fourth one is Maletswai Phasha.  The fifth one was Mamelele Phasha.  The sixth one was Abraham Madibeng Phasha.
I might have misunderstood you, but wasn't there another name, Jan Phasha, or was it one of the people that you've already listed?  Jan Mashyani Phasha.
He did not mention Jan Phasha's name as one of the people who bewitched him, but he was actually exposed by the traditional doctors who were called by the chief.
Now amongst those names mentioned, you mentioned the name Abraham Phasha, Abraham Madibeng Phasha, is that not correct?
And there was another name that I would like to put to you, Johannes Mamletswa Phasha.
Now was Johannes Phasha also pointed out as a witch or moloi?
I beg your pardon, Maletswai.  Was he also pointed out to be one of the molois?
Sorry, just explain that.  Pointed out by who?
Who pointed Johannes Maletswai Phasha as a moloi?
He was named by Moses before we went to the traditional doctors.  He was firstly mentioned by Moses, as one of the people who were troubling him.
And which of the traditional doctors mentioned his name?
The first doctor is the one who used the mirror, but I forgot his name, and the second one's name is Makwebelani Moloto and Ditoi Ghapola.
Now were you present when Abraham Madibeng Phasha died?
How many people stoned him to death?
Now of those 500 people who were present when he was stoned to death, who was the first person to throw a stone?
If I recall well, the first person to stone him was myself.

Now at that time, and as you gave evidence, you were active within the ANC support group as a supporter, there was a cry amongst the youth as to what should be done with impimpis and molois, what was that cry?
The youth were concerned that the witches were killing people who would be future leaders of the ANC, and such people should be killed if it is found that he had done that.
Who did the youth believe the witches supported on a political level?
As youth we believed that the witches supported the people who were against the aspirations of the ANC, that is to fight for freedom.
I'm referring to people who were against the aspirations of the ANC, like political parties who supported the then government to suppress black people.
Forgive me, Chairperson, if I listen to the interpreters dialogue, I thought some names were mentioned.  I'd like to hear the names.  What were those names again?
No, I did not mention names of people.
Were there local persons in the Northern Province, in your area, who supported the apartheid government?
According to my knowledge one such person was the King, who was our leader, because he supported the then government.
Now did that person have any particular relationship with either ngakas or molois?
I believe that they had dealings with the witches, then the doctors.
And what did that person who was a leader of your area, who supported the apartheid government, want of the molois?
His name was Mpho Nylete William Mashabela.
And what did Mr Mashabela want the molois to do for him, according to your belief or knowledge?
Amongst other things that I think he wanted the witches to do for him, was to fight against the youth who belonged to the ANC Youth League, so that the ANC Youth League should not develop.
How would that fight have been carried out?
I believe that amongst other things that would be done would be to kill the youth, like they did to Moses Phasha.

Right, let's go back to Moses Phasha's disappearance around the 16th of January.  How long did it take for you to notice that your brother had gone missing?  Did you notice it immediately or was he missing for a few days before you noticed?

Like I've already said that he was a sickly person, the first day he disappeared we became aware that he was missing because we could not find him in any of the family households, and that is how we realised that he has disappeared.
What efforts were made to search for him?

Before the community became involved, the family and relatives started searching for him, even in other villages where we thought that he might be there, but after realising that he was nowhere in those areas we went to seek for help from the traditional doctors.  We wanted them to show us whether he has disappeared or not and if he has disappeared, what could have been the cause for his disappearance.
And what did the traditional doctors tell you?
They told us that Moses has been abducted.
And what had happened to him as a result of his abduction?

The person who was actually involved in that was Jan Mashyani.  He was the person who was in contact with the traditional doctors and then he would take that to Moses' family, and then he said the doctors said he has disappeared, he has been abducted by the traditional doctors.
By the witches rather.  I'm sorry.
Now who said Jan Pasha was involved?  I didn't quite follow.  The traditional ngaka the nyanga?

Jan Mashyani Phasha was the person who was involved in the family, to help the family to find out from the traditional doctors what happened to Moses and what help is available from the traditional doctors to find him, so he would take the report from the doctors to the family.  In other words, he was the person who was the link between the family and the traditional doctors.
Now does that mean that Jan Phasha was pointed out as a moloi?
No, he was not pointed out as a witch, but he was the person who had the knowledge about Moses and what happened to Moses and what were the reasons for his disappearance.
Now was he the only one pointed out?
I don't understand your question, do you mean him being pointed out as a witch?
Well he was pointed out as being involved with the witches in Moses' disappearance.  My question then is, how many others were pointed out at this stage, as being involved?

No, no, Mr Richard, the applicant is saying that Jan Phasha was not pointed out as a witch, he was a go-between between the family and the traditional doctors, in order to try and find out what had happened to the deceased.  So he wasn't pointed out as a witch, hew as simply helping the family.

I stand corrected, thank you.
	Now what did you do with that information?

As family members or relatives, we were trying all the means to find, or to look for him where we thought he could be.  We even informed the chiefs in the neighbouring villages, asking them to tell us whenever they see him.
Now did you consult ngakas again, so as to find out what had happened to Moses?

The reason why we went back to the traditional doctors was that Jan Phasha went back to them to ask for help because they are they are the people who knew what happened to him.  He asked them to help the family by returning Moses back to the family.
And what did the traditional doctors say in response to Jan's request?
What Mashyani Phasha told us was that the traditional doctors have instructed him to go where Moses was hidden and then he'll be able to find him there, and that is where he was found.
Now before he was found - let me put the question this way, at what stage did the youth of the area become involved?

After that Jan returned from the traditional doctors, he went to the chief.  He requested the chief to give him some members of the community to go with him to that place where the traditional doctors said he will find Moses at, and that is how the youth were also involved in this issue.
How did the chief react to Jan Phasha's request?

The chief agreed and he wrote letters and he sent those letters to various schools in that village, instructing the schools that they should stop with their activities so that everybody can help in the search for Moses.

Now if you turn to paragraph 10(b) at page 15 of your application, there you say
"There were one of the ANC Youth League at KwaMatabela village, who had been lost.  The people of Matabela village include with the ANC youth at that village, were started to be angry and their captain, mentioned at paragraph 9(c), was granted letters to two high schools in his village to release the students to be helped by hunting that lost person to the mountain caves."
What do you mean "to the mountain caves"?  What do you mean by that?  Where are the mountain caves?
This mountain I'm referring to is in our village.

The problems that ensued at the mountain was that after that the youth have searched the mountain and they did not find Moses, they became angry towards the chief because they did not find Moses, so they wanted to know from the traditional doctor what has actually happened.
How many people went to the mountain cave?
More than 500 people, because there were so many people there.
Now when the search for Moses was unsuccessful, what happened next?

Because Mashyani Phasha was confronted by the youth he gave the youth the names of the people who were involved in Moses' disappearance.  That is when the youth decided that it will be better if they can get those people who have been mentioned as witches, so that those people could help in the search for Moses.
Now did they act out what had to be done on that decision?
They went to the chief's kraal.
And what did they do there?

When they arrived there they took a decision that they have to go and fetch those people who were alleged to be the witches, so that they could come and help the community.  And they indeed went out to fetch those people.
And when was it that Abraham Madibeng was named as the person responsible for Moses' disappearance?
Abraham was named together with people like Mano Gomaletswai Phasha and others and Abraham Madibeng Phasha.
Who names Abraham Phasha, who specifically named him as a witch?
He was named by Jan Mashyani Phasha.
Thank you.  Now on the day that Abraham Madibeng Phasha died, were any efforts made to apprehend and seize any other people names as witches?
That is correct, but they were not found.
So on this day, where was your brother, your co-applicant, Daniel Lisufi Phasha?

Daniel Lisufi Phasha, when Madimeng Phasha was killed, he had gone out with another group that went to search for the other witches, but he left after he asked the community to accuse Madibeng, because the community was angry and he was afraid that in trying to protect him he could also be killed and people may also suspect him as a witch.  That is why he left with this other group.
From your answer I understand that Daniel wasn't present while the stoning was happening, is that correct?
Now when did he arrive in the village, was it that day or the day before?
He arrived on the same day, the same day Madibeng was killed.

I did not see him when he arrived, but that was sometime after 6 o'clock in the afternoon and that is when I realised that he was present, then I was surprised to see him because I knew him to have been at Secunda.
Now you made a statement that he left because he had tried to dissuade the crowd from doing anything to Madibeng Phasha, did I understand you correctly?
May you please repeat that question?
I'll put it slightly differently.  Did Daniel agree that Abraham Madibeng Phasha should have something done to him?
I don't think that he agreed, but he only tried to help protect Madibeng, but now because he could not do that, he left, because the community was angry.
Did he know that - at the time he left, would he have known that Madibeng Phasha was in danger of being killed?
I believe that he knew that there was a possibility that Madibeng could be killed, due to the fact that the community was very angry.
He went out with the other group that was going to search for other witches.
Now had any stones been thrown at the time he left?
They had not yet started throwing stones when he left.
If he had returned with other people that had been named as witches, what would have happened to those other people?
The way I understood from Daniel and the way I heard what Jan Mashyani Phasha said, was that those witches should come and help find Moses Phasha, not that those witches should be killed.
Now at the time there was this crowd of 500 people around the deceased, were they singing and chanting?
What were they singing, what songs?
What do those words mean in English?
One of the songs that they sang was about Maletswai Phasha, that he was undermining the community, because Maletswai was regarded as the senior witch.
Isn't it also true that they were singing a song which has words, which translate into English as "Kill the impimpi, kill the witch"?
That is one of the songs, but in most of the cases they will sing about Maletswai.

I believe, Chairperson, my learned colleagues can take it further in cross-examination, I've laid the basis.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR RICHARD
Yes, does that conclude the evidence-in-chief?

Thank you, Mr Chairperson.  Mr Chairperson, although I don't have proper instructions, I would just have a few questions which I want to clarify with the applicant.
	Mr Phasha, you testified that the youth then left to the chief's kraal, were you part of the youth at the time when they went to the chief's kraal?
Did you regard the chief as your enemy?
Why then did you go to your enemy's kraal?
As a member of the community I went where the community was going and I wanted to be part of the meeting and to get what we were looking for.
Was this meeting attended by both old and young people?
Was the chief regarded as an enemy of only the youth, or both the old and the youth?
I wouldn't be certain about the community as a whole, but I am certain that he was regarded as the youth's enemy.
How many people died before the disappearance of Moses?
Many people, such that I won't be able to tell the number.

If I can just come in there.
	Can you sort of explain under what circumstances such people would die?

I may not know the reasons why they were killed, but there were suspicions about their deaths.  Like we know that a person can die due to an accident, or become ill and die, but their deaths were very suspicious.
Tell us more about that.  Why were such people's deaths suspicious, suspicious to who?
At that time they were suspecting the whites.  I just want to know whether you mean that whether those people suspected the whites or not, I was actually not answering.

Yes, but you say a lot of people died before Moses disappeared and I have asked you in what kind of situations would these people die, would it be car accidents, people falling sick and dying, or old people just dying because their life has come to an end? You know, that sort of thing.
One of them, if I remember well, died after he had fallen from the bed.  The other one died because it was said he was struck by lightening.
Can I take it that you are not suggesting that there was anything political about the circumstances in which those people had died?  You're not suggesting any politics in that.
I believe that because at that time people were not yet involved in politics, they became involved after the - around the death of Moses.
Thank you.  I'm sorry about that, Mr Mokoena, I just wanted that clarity.

Okay, thank you.
	Mr Phasha, you said your leader was supporting the previous government and therefore used these witches to fight the youth, who were inspired with the motives or whatever, of the ANC.  Now what I want to find out is, how did - or what exactly did these witches do to fight the youth?
Amongst other things that they would do would be to kill the youth, like the community believed that they were killed by the witches.

Now from your evidence-in-chief it appears to me as if there was a healthy relation between the chief and the community as such, because the chief also allowed his people to go and assist Mr Jan Phasha in searching for the missing person and also even wrote letters to the school requesting their assistance.  Why would the chief be so much involved in the searching of the missing person, if he was involved with this moloi?
I believe he did that because he was under pressure from the community and the youth.
Was there - prior to the missing of Moses, was there any stage where the youth and the chief had a direct consultation?
I'm saying, prior to the missing of Moses, was there any stage whether the youth and the chief had a confrontation?

There were conflicts between the chief and the community and the community was helped by the youth in trying to resolve those conflicts between the chief and the community.  But at that time there had never been any physical fight, they would be involved in verbal confrontations only, until the disappearance of Moses.
Can you just explain, what were these disputes about between the youth and the chief?

One of the conflicts was that there was an allegation that the chief was misappropriating the community funds and it was said that he could not develop the community like other communities were developing.

Sorry, just for my clarity, are you still talking about the same chief you said would be approached from time-to-time by people from the community who had problems and they wanted to know from the chief where to go for assistance from a ngaka, a witch-doctor?
That is correct, that's the same chief.
You say in spite of all those problems, people continued to approach the chief for assistance and guidance?
That was happening because the community respected the chief, they did not care how he was carrying himself out, but now because he was the chief, they really respected him.
Mr Phasha, did the chief restrict your political movements, or maybe meetings or demonstrations?
There is a meeting that he disrupted and he told us that he doesn't want us to hold political meetings in his village, and that is when we realised that he was against the youth.
Did he prevent maybe the, not necessarily the youth, but the ANC members, not being the youth only, the ANC, say the ...(indistinct) from meeting?
When he started preventing the youths meeting it was at the time when we were launching the ANC Youth League, that is why I say he was particularly against the ANC Youth League.
Okay.  And did he belong any other political organisation?

As to whether he was a member of a particular political organisation, we did not have that, but I believe that according to his actions, or following his actions, it was evident that he was a supporter of a certain political organisation, although I may not be able to specifically say which organisation.

I thank you, Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MOKOENA
Thank you, Mr Mokoena.  Ms Mtanga.

Thank you, Chairperson.
	Mr Phasha, in your evidence you've testified that before your brother's disappearance numerous people had died.
You grew up in a community that believed in witchcraft, would I be correct to say that?
Can you tell this Committee as to whether every time a person died in your community, did you believe that person was killed by the witches, or was bewitched by the witches?
We would only suspect that he has been bewitched if there is reasons for suspicions, and then we would consult the traditional doctors, we would not just suspect witchcraft in any death.
Can you give an example of a death where you wouldn't suspect witchcraft?
Like I mentioned that a certain girl fell from her bed and died.
So in that case you did not suspect witchcraft?

Because there were no actions taken, I can say we did not - there was no suspicion of witchcraft, but Moses' death raised suspicions because it was further confirmed by the traditional doctors and it was at that time that the people started to suspect that even the previous death of that girl was due to witchcraft.

When you suspected that a person had been killed by the witches, or when it was confirmed by your traditional doctors that such a person was killed by the witches, how would you know what the motive of the witches for killing this person was?  How would you know the motive of the witches?
May you please repeat the question.

I'm asking you, in the instance where a person is killed by the witches and you have this confirmation from the traditional doctor, how would you as the community know why did the witches kill the person?  How would you know the motives of the witches for killing that person?
The community will learn from the traditional doctors.
Can you give us a case where a witch-doctor told you what the reason was for the killing of a particular person, and what did he give those reasons to be?
I don't understand whether you say I should give you an example related to the death of Moses, or any other death that took place there.
I want an example other than the death of Moses, another example where you knew what the reasons for this killing of this person were.

I have been told that the traditional doctors would actually give reasons why the witches would kill a person.  I learnt that after the death of Moses, because before the death of Moses, we didn't have suspicions.
What did the traditional doctors say were the reasons for the killing of Moses?
They said the witches wanted to use him or his body parts to make traditional medicines.
If your brother Moses was killed because the witches wanted to use him for their purposes, what did this have to do with politics?  Why would his death then be political?

His killing is associated with politics because this doctor explained that Moses was the supporter and a member of the ANC Youth League at that village under Chief Mashabela, and the chief had actually tried to prevent the ANC Youth League from developing, and that is one of the reasons why Moses was killed.
Which traditional doctor told you this?

This traditional doctor was not telling me, but he was telling Jan Phasha, from whom we got this report.  I do not know his name, but I know this traditional doctor comes from Taung in the Driekop district.
My understanding of your evidence was that six people were shown by the witch-doctor on the mirror, as people who had caused the disappearance of your brother, am I correct?

Okay, let me put it this way.  The six people, Mamoghe Phasha, Reisiki Phasha, Reisibi Mashabela, Mamelele Phasha - I can't pronounce the name properly, but your father's aunt, were pointed out by a witch-doctor, how were they pointed out by the witch-doctor?  How did you know it was them who were behind the disappearance of your father?  How did you know?
From the report we were given by Jan Phasha, there was a doctor who was using a mirror to show those people who were alleged to have been involved in his disappearance.

At the point when you were giving this evidence, why didn't you state that the witch-doctor - when he showed these people the mirror where the six people appeared, why did you not mention that the reasons were given by the witch-doctor that your brother was killed because of his political activities?

From the evidence that I have tendered here I was answering according to the questions that were being asked.  I was not asked about what you say I was supposed to have said.  It is because maybe you did not ask me about that.
To which political organisation - or what was the political affiliation of Mamoghe Phasha?
I do not know in which political organisation Mamoghe Phasha belonged.
Did you know - okay, finish your sentence.
I do not have any knowledge about the political party she belonged to, the only thing that I believe is that she was being used to be against the youth.

Like I have heard from her that she was used, I heard this from Mamoghe Phasha, that there was a person who was their senior or their leader in witchcraft and he was the person who was using them and that was Maletswai Phasha.
What was the political affiliation of Maletswai Phasha?
I do not know in which political organisation did he belong.
Your uncle, Abraham Phasha was killed, can you tell us who gave orders for him to be killed?
